deck.name: Physical Readiness Training (PRT)
deck.description: FM 7-22 - Army Physical Readiness Training doctrine, ACFT events, H2F, training principles, and exercise techniques

metadata.title: Holistic Health and Fitness
metadata.proponent: United States Army Center for Initial Military Training

cards.front: What are the six events of the Army Combat Fitness Test (ACFT)?
cards.back:
1. 3 Repetition Maximum Deadlift (MDL)
2. Standing Power Throw (SPT)
3. Hand Release Push-Up (HRP)
4. Sprint-Drag-Carry (SDC)
5. Plank (PLK)
6. 2-Mile Run (2MR)

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-3)

cards.front: What is the minimum passing score for each ACFT event?
cards.back:
60 points per event, 360 total to pass. Maximum is 100 per event, 600 total.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-8)

cards.front: What weight equals 60 points on the MDL?
cards.back:
140 lbs (minimum passing).

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, Table 10-1)

cards.front: What weight equals 100 points on the MDL?
cards.back:
340 lbs (maximum score).

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, Table 10-1)

cards.front: What are the available MDL weight options?
What type of bar is used for the MDL?
cards.back:
60-lb hex bar (trap bar).

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-15)

cards.front: How many repetitions must be completed for the MDL?
cards.back:
Three repetitions without stopping. Must touch plates to ground between reps.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-15)

cards.front: What weight is the medicine ball for the SPT?
cards.back:
10 pounds.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-22)

cards.front: How many attempts are allowed for the SPT?
cards.back:
One practice throw, then two record attempts. Better score counts.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-22)

cards.front: What is the minimum SPT distance for 60 points?
cards.back:
4.5 meters.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, Table 10-2)

cards.front: What is the maximum SPT distance for 100 points?
cards.back:
12.5 meters or greater.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, Table 10-2)

cards.front: What is the HRP technique?
cards.back:
Start prone, arms extended to sides (T), bring hands under shoulders, push up, lower until chest touches, extend arms to sides, repeat.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-28)

cards.front: How long is the HRP event?
cards.back:
2 minutes.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-28)

cards.front: What is the minimum HRP count for 60 points?
cards.back:
10 repetitions.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, Table 10-3)

cards.front: What is the maximum HRP count for 100 points?
cards.back:
60 repetitions or more.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, Table 10-3)

cards.front: What are the five elements of the Sprint-Drag-Carry?
cards.back:
Sprint (25m), Drag (90-lb sled 25m), Lateral shuffle (25m down/back), Carry (2x40-lb kettlebells 25m down/back), Sprint (25m).

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-35)

cards.front: What is the total distance of the SDC?
cards.back:
250 meters (5 x 50m shuttles).

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-35)

cards.front: What is the minimum SDC time for 60 points?
cards.back:
3:00 (three minutes).

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, Table 10-4)

cards.front: What is the maximum SDC time for 100 points?
cards.back:
1:33 or faster.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, Table 10-4)

cards.front: What is the correct Plank position?
cards.back:
Elbows bent 90° under shoulders, forearms flat, body straight from shoulders to ankles, head aligned with spine.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-42)

cards.front: What is the minimum Plank time for 60 points?
cards.back:
1:00 (one minute).

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, Table 10-5)

cards.front: What is the maximum Plank time for 100 points?
cards.back:
3:20 or longer.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, Table 10-5)

cards.front: What is the minimum 2MR time for 60 points?
cards.back:
21:00 (twenty-one minutes).

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, Table 10-6)

cards.front: What is the maximum 2MR time for 100 points?
cards.back:
13:30 or faster.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, Table 10-6)

cards.front: What rest is required between ACFT events?
cards.back:
Minimum 2 minutes, maximum 5 minutes.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-10)

cards.front: In what order must ACFT events be completed?
cards.back:
MDL → SPT → HRP → SDC → PLK → 2MR (always in this sequence).

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-10)

cards.front: How often should Soldiers take a record ACFT?
cards.back:
Minimum twice per year (semi-annually). At least 4 months between record tests.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-5)

cards.front: What are the five components of Holistic Health and Fitness (H2F)?
cards.back:
Physical, Nutritional, Mental, Sleep, and Spiritual Readiness.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 1, para 1-4)

cards.front: What is Physical Readiness in H2F?
cards.back:
Developing strength, endurance, and mobility to perform physical tasks.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 1, para 1-5)

cards.front: What is Nutritional Readiness in H2F?
cards.back:
Proper fueling for performance, recovery, and health through diet.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 1, para 1-6)

cards.front: What is Mental Readiness in H2F?
cards.back:
Cognitive performance, emotional stability, and psychological resilience.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 1, para 1-7)

cards.front: What is Sleep Readiness in H2F?
cards.back:
Adequate quantity and quality of sleep for optimal performance.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 1, para 1-8)

cards.front: What is Spiritual Readiness in H2F?
cards.back:
Core values, purpose, and meaning that sustain a Soldier through adversity.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 1, para 1-9)

cards.front: What are the three phases of Physical Readiness Training?
cards.back:
Initial Conditioning (BCT), Toughening (later BCT/AIT), and Sustaining (unit level).

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 4, para 4-2)

cards.front: What are the seven principles of exercise?
cards.back:
Precision, Progression, Integration, Specificity, Overload, Recovery, Variety.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 3, para 3-5)

cards.front: What is the Precision principle?
cards.back:
Correct technique in every exercise to maximize benefit and minimize injury.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 3, para 3-6)

cards.front: What is the Progression principle?
cards.back:
Gradually increase difficulty over time to continue adaptation.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 3, para 3-7)

cards.front: What is the Overload principle?
cards.back:
Work beyond normal levels to stimulate adaptation and improvement.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 3, para 3-10)

cards.front: What is the Recovery principle?
cards.back:
Allow adequate rest between training sessions for adaptation to occur.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 3, para 3-11)

cards.front: What is the Specificity principle?
cards.back:
Train specifically for desired outcomes - training adaptations match training type.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 3, para 3-9)

cards.front: What are the three types of strength?
cards.back:
Muscular Strength (max force), Muscular Endurance (sustained force), Muscular Power (explosive force).

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 6, para 6-3)

cards.front: What is the recommended PRT session structure?
cards.back:
Preparation Drill (5-10 min), Activities (main training), Recovery Drill (5-10 min). Total 45-90 min.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 5, para 5-2)

cards.front: How many exercises are in the Preparation Drill?
cards.back:
10 exercises performed 5-10 reps each at moderate pace.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 5, para 5-8)

cards.front: What is the first exercise of the Preparation Drill?
cards.back:
Bend and Reach.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 5, para 5-8)

cards.front: What is the last exercise of the Preparation Drill?
cards.back:
Push-Up.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 5, para 5-8)

cards.front: Name the 10 Preparation Drill exercises.
cards.back:
Bend/Reach, Rear Lunge, High Jumper, Rower, Squat Bender, Windmill, Forward Lunge, Prone Row, Bent Leg Body Twist, Push-Up.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 5, para 5-8)

cards.front: How long are Recovery Drill stretches held?
cards.back:
20-30 seconds each.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 5, para 5-15)

cards.front: What are the 4 for the Core exercises?
cards.back:
Bent Leg Raise, Side Bridge (L/R), Back Bridge, Quadraplex.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 6, para 6-18)

cards.front: What are the Hip Stability Drills?
cards.back:
Lateral Leg Raise, Medial Leg Raise, Bent Leg Lateral Raise, Single Leg Tuck, Single Leg Over.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 6, para 6-22)

cards.front: What is the 30:60 interval method?
cards.back:
30 seconds high intensity, 60 seconds recovery. Start with 5-6 intervals, build to 10-12.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 7, para 7-12)

cards.front: What is the 60:120 interval method?
cards.back:
60 seconds high intensity, 120 seconds recovery. More challenging than 30:60.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 7, para 7-13)

cards.front: What is the standard foot march distance/weight?
cards.back:
12 miles with 35 lbs in 3 hours or less.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 7, para 7-22)

cards.front: How often should foot marches be conducted?
cards.back:
No more than twice per week with adequate recovery.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 7, para 7-22)

cards.front: What is Military Movement Drill 1 (MMD1)?
cards.back:
Verticals (high knee run), Laterals (shuffle), Shuttle Sprint. Performed over 25m.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 7, para 7-28)

cards.front: What is Military Movement Drill 2 (MMD2)?
cards.back:
Power Skip, Crossover, Crouch Run. More advanced than MMD1.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 7, para 7-32)

cards.front: What is Conditioning Drill 1?
cards.back:
Power Jump, V-Up, Mountain Climber, Leg Tuck and Twist, Single Leg Push-Up.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 6, para 6-25)

cards.front: What is Conditioning Drill 2?
cards.back:
Turn and Lunge, Supine Bicycle, Half Jacks, Swimmer, 8-Count T Push-Up.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 6, para 6-25)

cards.front: What is Conditioning Drill 3?
cards.back:
Y Squat, Single Leg Dead Lift, Side-to-Side Knee Lift, Front Kick Alternate Toe Touch, Tuck Jump.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 6, para 6-25)

cards.front: What rest is recommended for heavy strength training (1-5 reps)?
cards.back:
2-5 minutes between sets.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 6, para 6-8)

cards.front: What rest is recommended for moderate strength training (6-12 reps)?
cards.back:
1-2 minutes between sets.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 6, para 6-8)

cards.front: What rest is recommended for endurance training (12+ reps)?
cards.back:
30-60 seconds between sets.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 6, para 6-8)

cards.front: What are the signs of overtraining?
cards.back:
Decreased performance, persistent fatigue, increased resting heart rate, disturbed sleep, irritability, increased injuries.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 3, para 3-18)

cards.front: What is the recommended minimum sleep for Soldiers?
cards.back:
7-9 hours per night for optimal performance.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 8, para 8-3)

cards.front: What Heat Category suspends outdoor ACFT?
cards.back:
Heat Category V (Black Flag) - commander's discretion, consider postponing.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-12)

cards.front: What weather condition suspends the ACFT?
cards.back:
Lightning within 6 miles suspends outdoor testing.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 10, para 10-12)

cards.front: What is the Guerilla Drill exercise?
cards.back:
Combination exercise: squat thrust, push-up, lunge, sprint. Develops muscular endurance.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 6, para 6-30)

cards.front: What is Climbing Drill 1?
cards.back:
Power Jump, Pull-Up, Leg Tuck. Develops upper body pulling strength.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 6, para 6-28)

cards.front: What is Climbing Drill 2?
cards.back:
Flexed-Arm Hang, Heel Hook, Pull-Up. More advanced climbing preparation.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 6, para 6-29)

cards.front: What is the Push-Up and Sit-Up Drill (PSD)?
cards.back:
Alternating push-ups and sit-ups in sets to develop upper body and core muscular endurance.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 6, para 6-32)

cards.front: What is an Ability Group Run?
cards.back:
Formation run organized by fitness level. Soldiers run with others of similar ability.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 7, para 7-5)

cards.front: What is a Release Run?
cards.back:
Individual-paced run for distance. Soldiers run at their own pace.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 7, para 7-6)

cards.front: What is Terrain Running?
cards.back:
Running over varied surfaces and grades to develop functional endurance.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 7, para 7-8)

cards.front: What is the recommended progression for foot marches?
cards.back:
Start 3 miles/35 lbs at 20 min/mile. Add distance before adding weight.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 7, para 7-22)

cards.front: What is the FITT principle?
cards.back:
Frequency, Intensity, Time, Type - the variables to manipulate in exercise programming.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 3, para 3-15)

cards.front: What does RICE stand for in injury treatment?
cards.back:
Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation. Basic acute injury management.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 9, para 9-5)

cards.front: What is the daily caloric intake recommendation for active Soldiers?
cards.back:
3,000-4,500 calories per day depending on activity level and body size.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 8, para 8-12)

cards.front: What is the recommended protein intake for Soldiers?
cards.back:
1.2-2.0 grams per kilogram of body weight per day.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 8, para 8-15)

cards.front: What is the recommended hydration before exercise?
cards.back:
17-20 oz 2-3 hours before, and 8 oz 20-30 minutes before.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 8, para 8-20)

cards.front: What is the recommended hydration during exercise?
cards.back:
7-10 oz every 10-20 minutes during exercise.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 8, para 8-21)

cards.front: What are common overuse injuries in PRT?
cards.back:
Stress fractures, shin splints, tendinitis, plantar fasciitis. Caused by too much too soon.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 9, para 9-8)

cards.front: What is the 10% rule for progression?
cards.back:
Increase training volume (distance, weight, reps) by no more than 10% per week.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 3, para 3-7)

cards.front: What is the Shoulder Stability Drill?
cards.back:
I-Raise, T-Raise, Y-Raise. Develops shoulder stability and prevents injury.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 6, para 6-24)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the Preparation Drill?
cards.back:
Warm up muscles, increase heart rate, improve flexibility before main activity.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 5, para 5-5)

cards.front: What is the purpose of the Recovery Drill?
cards.back:
Cool down, reduce muscle soreness, improve flexibility, promote recovery.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 5, para 5-12)

cards.front: What is dynamic stretching?
cards.back:
Active movements that stretch muscles through their range of motion. Used in warm-up.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 5, para 5-6)

cards.front: What is static stretching?
cards.back:
Holding a stretch position for 20-30 seconds. Used in cool-down, not warm-up.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 5, para 5-14)

cards.front: What is the H2F System?
cards.back:
Holistic Health and Fitness - comprehensive system addressing physical, mental, spiritual, nutritional, and sleep readiness.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 1, para 1-2)

cards.front: What does the H2F Performance Team include?
cards.back:
Strength and conditioning coaches, physical therapists, dietitians, mental performance specialists, athletic trainers.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 2, para 2-5)

cards.front: What is the goal of the Initial Conditioning Phase?
cards.back:
Build foundation of fitness during BCT/IET. Prepare body for more intense training.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 4, para 4-3)

cards.front: What is the goal of the Toughening Phase?
cards.back:
Develop combat fitness during later BCT/AIT. Increase intensity and complexity.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 4, para 4-4)

cards.front: What is the goal of the Sustaining Phase?
cards.back:
Maintain and improve fitness at unit level. Continue professional development.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 4, para 4-5)

cards.front: How should PRT be scheduled in a training week?
cards.back:
3-5 sessions per week, allowing 48 hours between intense sessions for the same muscle groups.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 4, para 4-8)

cards.front: What is periodization?
cards.back:
Systematic variation of training to prevent plateaus and optimize performance over time.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 3, para 3-20)

cards.front: What are macrocycles, mesocycles, and microcycles?
cards.back:
Macrocycle = year, Mesocycle = 3-4 weeks, Microcycle = 1 week. Training planning periods.

(Source: FM 7-22, Ch 3, para 3-21)
